sections.title: ACL
paragraphs: The Association for Computational Linguistics is an international professional society with membership open to any person or institution whose professional goals relate to computational linguistics. Federation of Information Processing Societies, and is also associated with the International Committee on Computational Linguistics. Subscriptions to the AJCL are available only through membership in the ACL. Each subscription includes both hard-copy and microfiche versions of the Journal. Annual membership dues are $15 for individuals and $30 for institutions. Joint memberships for couples are available for $20, but provide only one subscription. Postage: The AJCL is normally mailed bulk-rate. First class mailing is available in North America for an additional annual charge of $6. Air-printed mailing is available overseas for an additional annual charge of $12. Back issues of the AJCL for the years 1974-1978 are available on microfiche only. The rates per annual volume are $15 for individuals and $30 for institutions. First class mailing of back issues is available in North America for an additional charge of $3 per volume. Air-printed mailing of back issues is available overseas for an additional charge of $6 per volume. There were no issues in 1979. Payments for dues or back issues should be sent to the ACL Secretary-Treasurer at the address given above. Checks should be made out to the Association for Computational Linguistics (or to ACL) and should be payable in U.S. dollars. There is an additional $1 charge for bank processing costs for checks that are not drawn on U.S. banks. Address changes should be sent to the ACL Secretary-Treasurer at the address given above.

This issue contains 94 pages, which is almost double the 50 pages per quarterly issue stated in my original proposal for producing this hard-copy

sections.title: Journal.
paragraphs: [Details may be found in the news article on page 49 of the January-March 1980 issue of

sections.title: AJCL
paragraphs: and in the proposal reproduced on page 68 in the Microfiche Supplement of that issue.] The first two quarterly issues of 1980 consisted of 62 and 64 hard-copy pages, respectively. These three issues together, then, provide a total of 220 hard-copy pages for the year (plus 9 pages of Microfiche Supplement). Included in these issues are nine rather long technical articles (130 pages), ten book reviews (16 pages), 133 abstracts (34 pages), a complete membership list (18 pages), and announcements, minutes and programs of meetings, etc. (22 pages).

In July, Michael McCord of the University of Kentucky became Associate Editor, and in October, Andrea McKenzie of IBM Research became Editorial Assistant. Both of these people contributed substantially to the publication of this issue.

In 1981 we intend to publish four smaller issues on a more nearly regular schedule. We currently have about 25 articles being refereed, about 25 books to be reviewed, and a backlog of about 25 abstracts to publish. But, we would like to have still more. We continue to welcome submissions of technical articles and other material (especially abstracts of technical reports and announcements of meetings) according to the guidelines given on the inside back cover.
